- Crataegus sanguinea, also known as redhaw hawthorn or Siberian hawthorn, produces edible red berry-like fruits called "haws". These fruits can be eaten raw or cooked, used to make jam, jelly, and fruit preserves, and are also grown in gardens as ornamental plants.
- Most species of "Crataegus" (hawthorn) have red fruit, while others can have black, purple, yellow, or orange fruit.
- The common hawthorn, "C. monogyna", produces edible "haws" that can be used to make jelly or homemade wine. The leaves and flower buds are also edible and used in salads. In the southern United States, the fruits of native hawthorn species are made into jellies known as mayhaws.
- Crataegus erythropoda, native to the southern Rocky Mountains, produces dark purplish red "haws".
- Crataegus pinnatifida, also known as mountain hawthorn or Chinese hawthorn, produces bright red fruits that are used to make Chinese snacks, jams, jellies, juices, alcoholic beverages, and other drinks.
- Crataegus rufula, or rusty hawthorn, is one of several species of hawthorn with fruits known as "mayhaws", which are harvested for use in making mayhaw jelly.
- Crataegus maximowiczii is a species of hawthorn with red to purple-black fruits.
